div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: Egyptian Army
div.p: El Bimbashi W. B. C. Bridge, 9th Sudanese, has been struck off the strength of the Egyptian Army

div.head: An Official Mission.
div.p: Aziz Pacba Izzet is, it is said, going on an official mission to Italy on behalf of the Government.

div.head: Penny Postage.
div.p: With fleet from the 15th February 1906, penny postage will be extended to letters exchanged between Egypt and the Sudan, and Bermuda and the Bahamas.

div.head: Fire at Printing Works.
div.p: A fire broke ont yesterday in a printing establishment on the Wakfs property at Shader El Battikh. It was quickly extinguished by the fire brigade. The damage has not yet been estimated.

div.head: The Shrsgsr Bankruptcy.
div.p: A Calcutta correspondent informs os lhat the winding up of Shrager Brothers will be a long affair, and that it is believed that 2s. in t he £ will be paid to the oreditors.

div.head: Municipal Commission.
div.p: There will be a meeting of the Alexandria Munioipal Commission at 4 p.m., on Wednes-day next, the 14th inst., at the Munioipal Palace. The matters to be disoussed will be the sequel of the "Ordre da Jour" of the meeting on the 10th inst.

div.head: Swiss Consulate.
div.p: The scheme of establishing Swiss consula-tes in Alexandria and Cairo is being seriously entertained. The Swiss Colony in Egypt has been increasing rapidly of late years, and a large amount of Swiss capital is being invested in Egypt.

div.head: Promotion.
div.p: The following promotion, made in aooor- danoe with the decision of the Counoil of Ministers dated 1-2-06, has been made :— Mohamed Mahmud Suliman Effendi, Private Secretary to the Adviser, to be Private Se-cretary, with pay at the rats of L.E. 400 per annum.

div.head: Still They Come.
div.p: A large number of tourists are due to arrive at Alexandria to-monow by the White 8tar liner Republio from the United States. The agents. Messrs. John Ross & Co., inform ns that they have reoeived a telegram from Naples ann on Doing that she should arrive here at daybreak. The Celtio arrived at New York from Alexandria on the 11th inst., at 10 a.m., after a very pleasant voyage.

div.head: Mme. Florignl Zervelli's Recital.
div.p: The fallowing is the programme of the Pianoforte Reoital to be given at the Popular Uni versity to morrow evening at 9 15 : — Hnmo- reske, R Schumann ; "Casta Diva," Etnde sur la Norma poor one maiD, arraDgde par Listz ; Vake en Do diesis mineur, Chopin ; Andante spianato, Chopin ; Grande Polonaise, Chopin ; Herbstlied, Tiohaikowsky ; Souvenir d'ltalie, C. Saint-Satins ; Nnitamment, R. 8ohomann. Pleyel Pianoforte kindly lent by M. Lifonti.

div.head: Accident at Abou Hommos.
div.p: A very sad aooident ooonrred at Abon Hommos station on Sunday. A young native woman, about 20 years of age, made a dash at a train which was just leaving the station. Her mother and annt tried to prevent her boarding the train, bat she olotohed at a carriage and held on. The station-master seized hold of the girl and tried to make her leave go, and both fell under the wheels of the train. They are terribly injured and it is doubtful if they will survive.

div.head: A Pleasant Function.
div.p: On the occasion of tbeir leaving Alexandria for Cyprus, Lieut, and Mrs. Page, of the A.8.C., entertained the non-commissioned officers, men. and their wives belonging to the detachment, at the Green Home, Carlton, on Friday last. An enjoyable musical evening was spent, in the ccurse of which presentations of a silver card caie to Mrs. Page, and a silver oigarette case and silver mounted holder to Lieut. Page, were made.The good feeling and esprit deoorps which exis'ere between officers and men were suitably referred to,and the most cordial wishes were expressed for the success of the hosts in their new sphere of duty.

div.head: P. & O. Co;s Yachting Trips.
div.p: The P. and 0. yaoht Veotis will sail from Marseilles on February 17th for Greece, Syria, the Holy Land and Egypt, being due at Alex andria about the middle of Maroh. The itinerary of the vessel's following ornise, as at first planned, hss been altered, and the Veotis will not pay a visit to our port on the latter trip She will leave Marseilles again on the 12th April for a cruise which will embraoe, and the principal feature of which will be, a stay at Pirteus during the four concluding day* of the Olympian games at Athens, so that persons desirous of witnessing the games should book their passage on the yacht's arrival in Egypt next mouth.

div.head: FAILURE PREDICTED.
div.p: Gazette's Special Service.
London, Tuesday.
The London Press prediots the failure of the negotiations at the Conference at Algeciras.

div.head: POSITION OF THE UNIONIST PARTY
div.p: A speech just delivered by the late Prime Minister makes the Unionist party in favour of fiscal reform, one without definite methods of policy; and it leaves the Unionist Free Traders high and dry.

div.head: THE NEW LABOUR PARTY
div.p: LONDON, Tuesday.

Keir Hardie's leadership of the labour party involves the creation of a socialist group, as the result of the success of the party at the polls, but this is not to be considered unsatisfactory, as many of the party represent other interests and will enforce moderation.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK.
APPOINTMENT OF GOVERNOR.
LONDON ADVICE TO BE SOUGHT
div.p: We understand that at the interview which took place yesterday morning at the British Agency between Lord Cromer and the various directors and representatives of the bank several names were pat fotward, none of whioh, however, met with the necessary approval. Consequently the matter is for the moment in abeyance. It was suggested that some of the leading members among the London bankers ihonld by consulted, with a request that they might i uggest some well-known London banker, who would be willing to aocept the vaoaut Governorship. A meeting of the direotors of the bank WSR held in the afterncon, at which we understand, it was resolved to adopt the above.suggestion and that steps will at onoebe taken to seek the best London advioe. It is believed in Cairo that it is by no means improbable that none of the gentlemen Whpse names have been mentioned as' likely to be seleoted for the post will be finally chosen, and it is thought that an English banker of high standing will be seleoted. Piobate was granted yesterday at the British Consulate Cairo, to the two exeoutors of the late governor of the bank, Lady Palmer and the Hon. Bernard Franois Rollo, manager of the London branch of the bank. A telegram we published on Saturday an-nounced that in the event of Sir Vincent Caillard's appointment, Major Sir Edward FitzGerald Law K.C.M.G.,C.S.I., would snooeed him as obairman of the London Agenoy of the bank. Sir Edward Law was born at Rostrevor Nov. 2,1846, and is the third son of the late Miohael Law, of Dublin. He was married in 1898 to a daughter of Nioholas Hatsopoulo of Athens. He studied at the R.M.A. Woolwioh, was made Lieutenant in R. A. 1868, commanded transport in Guards Brigade, Saakin, 1885, (medal and clasp, Egyptian bronze star, mentioned in despatches) ; Captain, 1886; Major, 1886. He entered the diplomatio servioe as fi lanoi al and commercial secretary in 1887, and has seen muoh servioe abroad in various oapaoities. He filled the responsible position of financial member of the Governor-General's Counoil io India from l?00 to 1904.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Ghazi Mookhtar Pacha has returned to Cairo. We are glad to hear that the Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner is making as satisfactory progress as oan be expected after his reoent serious aooident. Sir William Garstin retarded to Cairo ou Sunday. The Hen. Harry LawsoD, eldest son of Lord Burnham, proprietor of the "Daily Telegraph," is staying at the Ghezireh Palaoe Hotel.

The "Times" gives the following aooount of Sir Charles Cookson's experiences daring the "Events" :In 1881 he had a remarkable and painful experience. It will be remembered that in that year a ory of 'Egypt for the Egyptians" was raised, and that Colonel Arabi Bey posed as champion of the Egyptian Army, which .demanded redress of its real or supposed grievances In September, 1881, a military demonstration was made in Abdeen-square, Cairo, and the Khedive was practically im-prisoned in his own palace. It fell to Mr. Cookson (as he then was), ass:sted by Mr. Colvin, to restore tranquillity, and his services in that behalf were acknowledged by making him a C.B. Nine months later an attack on Europeans was organised in Alexandria, and Mr. Cookson, deeming it his dnty to try to quell the disturbance by the authority of his presence, courageously drove in an open carriage to the head office of the police. On the way he was attaoked by the mob, felled to the ground by a nabout, and barely escaped with his life. Iu 1883 he was appointed British delegate on the International Commission which was oharged with the dnty of settling thedndemnitiei claimed by the sufierers in the Arabi riots after the British Fleet had bom-barded Alexandria, riots in the ooarse of which Mr. Cookson lost by fire the whole of his personal effects, including a valuable library.

Daring his retirement in London he devoted much of his leisure time to committees of the Chelsea Charity Organisation Society and the Coal Smoke Abatement Society. For several years he used in his own house no bituminous ooal, but only coke, which helgnited by pipes under the grate oonneoted with the ordinary gas sapply. Many persons oalled to inspect his method, which so lately as last month he explained at length in a paper road at a oon- forenoe of the Sanitary Iusfcifcate held in West-minster. He oaloalated that if his plan were naiversally adopted London would save some millions of pounds a year in repairs, painting, oleaning. eto., to say nothing of the joy of breathing an unpolluted atmosphere. He was the elder and only surviving brother of Mr. Montagae Craekanthorpe, K.C.

div.head: THE CAIRO SEASON.
div.p: Both Friday and Saturday evenings have seen balls at the Savoy, the R jdoute Rose being held on the former, and the usual small dance OJ the latter. The Rebate given by the Comity des Fates, was a pretty fanotion, and the decorations of the room lefc nothing to be lesired. But the evening was shorn of half its gbries by the fact that none of the gentlemen wore dominoes, aod there was bat little mystery aboat the wearers of the pretty pink garments and fluffy headgear. In nearly every case it wa9 possioleto identify the incognitas by their partners, for at this end of the reason, one knows fairly well who will be danoing with whom, and there is a noted antipathy among English people to danoiog with any oat of their immediate circle. There was no speo'al signal given for unmasking, but most ot the ladies were glad enough to discard their facial dis-guises after the first hour or so,though in many jams the becoming dominos were retained during the evening. Several ladies had effeo- taally disgaised themselves by wearing wigs of a different ooloar to their own coiffures, and one of the belles of Cairo completely mystified her admirers by hiding her raven tresses beneath loDg curs of golden hue. Most of the indefatigable dauoers were present, but the proportion of English visitors was not so greit as it generally is, nor was dancing con-tinued till each a late hour as usual. Bat ia spite of having danced cheer folly all through the week, there were bat few faces missing when Saturday night came round again, and there were various new arrivals to add to the quota of beauty and distinction. There were many new and pretty frocks to be seen, notably some very handsome ones in brocade and satin, and a - really becoming Empire frock, which is more than can be said of all of this type, in blae erfipe de Chine, with the bodioe confined by wide orossing hands of satin, and the fulness of the skirt kept in subjection by lines of gaaging following the lines of the satin. As usual paillettes and sequins and tinsel emhroderies, were greatly to the fore, and noticeable among the others was a lovely sequined robe in smoke grey made over grey, and with no relief beyond the big bnuch of violets tacked into the corsage. Another very effective dress of lace, made Princesse fashioD, was nearly hidden beneath the long narrow shaped aoplications of heliotrope satin, each application being outlined with a single row of tiny sequins. Lady Rogers was wearing a lovely frock ot soft rose satin, the lace at neck and sleeves being confined by twists of bine, ornamentations of the same blue appearing on the skirt. Mrs. Heivetson's frock of heliotrope taffetas had three rows of fine lace on the skirt, and the smartly cut oorsage had fichu-like ere telles of silk, edged with the lace draped apon it. Miss Gordon Scott was wearing a handsome Princesse gown of soft cream satin, the little laoe bolero heavily embroidered with pearls and silver sequins. Lady Hemming looked well in black satin with a flounoe and berthe of beautiful lace, and Mrs. Whittaker's dress was of lace with insertions of pale blue satin. Mrs. Rom had on a modified Em pire frock of a deep shade of cream, the short-waisted bodice all of laoe with narrow revers of old rose velvet, and the long skirt embroidered with big Empire wreaths of laarel leaves. Miss Severidge was wearing a well out white satin gown with draped bodice and bretelles, and Miss Boulter was also in white satin, very maoh oat off the shoulders Mrs. Galhenkian wore a beautiful gauze tnnio heavPy embroidered with softly gleaming sequins over a chiffon under-dress, and Mrs Rome's dainty black net dress, made over white, was lightly trimmed with groups of silver roses. Miss Kirkbride's brocade was cut with corselet skirt, the bodioe and fl iwiug sleeves of soft green chiffon. Miss Potter had on a dainty maslin over pink, very much befrilled, and decorated with tiny pink bows and wreaths of roses; one of the Misses Rogers was also in pink. Mrs. George Roy'e was in black with mach jet aboat it, and Mrs. Blakeney had on a black net overdress with long jet insertions over white, aod Mrs. Scott Dalgleish was in magpie colouring, relieved by touches of bine at the csinture and on the s'eaves. Mrs. Valentine Smith's handsome robe of lace and jet was worn over a soft blue foundation, and her niecs, Miss Ambridge, was wearing a pretty fresh blue taffotis with emplacement of dia- ment^e lace. The Misses York were both in Empire dresses, and Miss Whittaker was also wearing a gauzy pink robe of ths same period. One of the Misses Hurley was in a becoming bleck jet insertioned Princesse frock, and her tister, who has not yet quite recovered the hart she sustained at Mena on Tne'day, was in oream satin. Miss Suurt was in a pale shade of pink cfope de Chine and wore a wreath of green leaves in her hair. Mrs. Morgan was wearing a lace frock, as was Miss Joseph, the Mi-see Cole were in pale blue and pale pink respectively, with velvet trimmings to match. Miss de Biliritki was in white with bine velvet cretelles, and Miss Sampson vaa in a b'ack and white -potted si k muslin, with touches of bine on the shoulder straps. Miss Mcllvaine, was in uink, and Miss Rees was in pale bfae. A Photographic Contretemps Saturday's dance was highly successful, but for the attempt to photograph the dancers (who had stopped dancing) by flashlight. At the word of oommand everyone looked or tried to look, ornamental, when a |oa>i explosion of sheet inagnesinm dazz'ed and alarmed the expectant crowd, and fil'ed the room with a peculiarly unpleasant fog. The photographs shou'd be of valno to all who wish to caricature Cairo society. Many of tie ladies present, unprepared for the sudden explosion, shat their eyes or started, and the photograph, it accurate, will show unmerons men bars of the sterner sex framing or stiffing ejaoalatiois or opening their mouths and shutting their eyes in the most infantile way.

div.head: OLD EGYPT'S DOCTORS.
div.p: WERE SKILLED AT DIAGNOSIS. REMARKABLE PAPYRUS.

Dr. Klein, of Chicago, has recently read an elaborate paper before the American Academy of Medicine on the "Papyros Ebers " This is a roll of papyrus acquired by Dr. Ebers in the vicinity of Thebes in the winter of 187* from an Arab who made ancient grave robbing a business, and who had strnok a line of rock tombs undiscovered as yet by the others of the guild. He found this roll of papyrus between the legs of a mummy. It was single, tightly rolled, yellow brown, about a foot wide, and written over for the length of over 65 feet, in regular oolumns that are numbered. It is exactly preserved, and after investigation and translation was deposited in the library of the University of Leipz'g. It was cut in sections there, and placed betwoen glass forjmrposes of preservation and examination. The script of this papyrue is hieratic—and other scripts are hieroglyphic and demotio—a running script in red and black inks. Every heading\is in red ink. By certain signs, especial1 y an almanac on the outside and an inscription which refers to Amenophis I. the date of this papyrus is placed at about 1552 before Christ. But it has been established to the satisfaction of Egyptologists that the paper is hut a transcription or copy of an older work, which is put 3 COO years before that, and this places the original at a period of over 7,000 years ago. But the most marvellous matter about this papyrus is that it is a comprehensive treatise on medicine, as well class fiod and as logically arranged as any modern text-book. The diagnosis of diseases, is carefnlly given, their nature treated of, and the remedies arranged in logioal order. Diseases of the abdomen, the chest, the heart,the eyes and ears, and so on, are oarefully arranged and described in a manner that would hold water at the present day. For instance of the heart the papyrus classifies the troubles as: Fatty degeneration, di'atatioi, carditis, angina ot spasm, hypertrophy (enlargement), thrombosis (plugging) and dropsy. That comps pretty near to us. Of medicines over 7 different substances are enumerated, and they are prescribed in pills, in tabid s, in capsules, in decoctions, powders, inhalations, lotions, ointments, plasters. The completeness of the work, the Close observation, the logical division and the com- west the ore is 17 io. wide and goes 15 dwt., mon sense in treatment manifested in 1 his whilst the 245 ft. rise north east shows a valne ancient doooment are startlingly surprising of 1 oz. 19 dwt. for 31 in. At the deepest point to the modern man. These ancients had;—550 ft.—the ore body is about 1 ft. wide and their specialists, just as we. But, above all, : assays to the north-east 9 dwt. and to the is the revelation how much we thonght was . eouth west L3 dwt. Judging by recent develop- onr own discovery, which, it seems, was known ments, it would seem that there are better days to these Egyptian doctors 7,000 years ago. The ahead for the shareholders." anatomical and medical hints in the law of j In a circular accompanying the report of the Mcses are found olosely related to the t"xt Nile Valley Company (Limited), the direotors of this ancient papyrns, while many of the deplore the faot that rumours about reconstruction.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING
div.p: THE UM RUS MINE. NILE VALLEY RECONSTRUCTION.

The Progreps report No. 63 for the halfmonth ended the 15 th Jan nary is as follows : ' 550 ft level north-east—Was extended 3 ft, total 29 ft. Vein 12 inS wide; not sampled. 550 ft level south-wpst—Was extended 3 ft, total 12 ft. Vein pinched. No tample. 550 ft main wii ze—Was deepened 12 ft, making a depth of 28 ft below the 550 ft level. The vein is split in two and measures 18 ins, assaying 6 dwt 12 gra per ton 450 ft level northeast— Was advanced 7 ft, total distance 154 ft. Quartz averaged 11 ins wide, assaying 3 dwts 13 grs per ton. 450 ft. level south-west—Was advanced 9 ft, total distance 160 ft. Qaartz averaged 14 ins wide, assaying 2 ozs 4 dwts per ton. 350 ft. No. 2 winza north iiat—Was sunk 4 ft, making the required depth of 106 ft. Suspended. 350 ft level south-west—Was advanced 14 ft, miking a total distance of 417 ft. The quartz averaged 26 ins wide and 17 dwts 15 grs per ton in value. 245 ft level north-ea3t Was advanced 10 ft to a total ot 310 fr. The quartz 15 ins wide assayed a trace. 245 ft north-east winze 2 at 260 ft—Was sunk 11 ft. The quartz 12 ius wide assayed 17 dwts 7 gra per ton. In two Btopes below this level the quartz is 25 ins wide, worth 16 dwts 15 grs, and 17 ins worth 11 dwts 17 grs respectively. 245 ft level south-west—Was advanced 14 ft. making a total dittmce of 445 ft. Th« quar'z lOins wide assayed 7 dwts 20 grs per ton. At 436 ft, level holed into o'd stopes, which at this point extend to a few feet below the 245 ft level. 245 fc raiee at 16 ft no th- ea^t—Riseu 7 ft, malting a total of 15 ft. div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
div.p: LBS PROCHAINBS ELECTIONS LA PUBLICITE DE3 SEANCES Nos oonseillers munioipaux n'aiment pas la publicity ; ils Font bien montrd lore de la discussion an sujet de l'admisaion de la presse aux pdanoea. Ils n'aiment pas davantage les derangements ; ils Font prouvd par lenr absence rdgoliZe des reunions, an moins la majority d'entre eux. Le travail lenr siurit si pen qu'ils ont abdiqad le poavoir entre les mains de la Delegation et qu'ila jouent k pea prZ le iAle des roi« faineants & l'dpoque oil Quatre bceufs attelaj d'un pas tmnquille et lent Pi onwnaient dans Pai is le inonarque indolent. Cette oitation vient a point an moment oil l'imprdvoyanca de nos ddiles, jointe a leur farenr de doubler et de tripler les reoettes a enfin determine une grdve gdndrale des coobers, grdve qui porte an grave prdjadioe aux iutdrdts de la ville. Il n'y a gukre que deux oonseillers munici panx qui aient bien oompris la situation fausse oil se ddbat aotuellement la munioipalitd : ce sont MM. Alderson et Zouro. Tons deux ont luttd oontre las prerogative) monstrueuses de la Ddldgation, oontre l'apatb io de lenrs collogues et en favour de Fadmissiou de lapresseaux sdauces, comma oonttA e public de la gestion municipale. M. Alderson a m6me montrd une telle oha- leur dans le ddbat et a reuooutrd one telle hostility quil a dfi donner sa ddmisaion. Nous sommes beureux d'apprendre, oon- trairement it ce qu'on avait dit jaequ'ioi, que M. Alderson consent se representor, ainsi que M. Zouro. Le public ne manquera pas de les soutenir aux proobaines elections. Il y va de son propre iutdrdt. Grftoe it eux la oampagne en favour de Fadmissiou de la presse aux seances pourra dtre reprise et si olio aboutit, comma nous l'eapdrons, le public exercera ainsi un oontrdle direct sur les affaires muuioipales. On sait s'il y en a besoin.

div.head: UNE NOUVELLE SOCIETE
div.p: Nous publions, dautre part, l'avis relatif k la souscription publique de la "Sooidtd d'fintre- prises Immobilizes et des Travaux." Voioi lee passages saillant) du prospeotus de cette Society : La champ d'aotion de la Society est des plus larges. Elie pourra acheter, vendre on prendre k bail tous terrains it bitir on de oultare soit pour son oompte, soit pour oompte de tiers. Les transactions immobilizes ont pris un tel ddveloppement, an Cairo et dans les provinces, qu'elle pourra s'assurer an important revenu annuel da seal chef des courtages proveuant des operations dans lesquelles elle agira en intermediate entre acbeteurs et vendenrs, entre propnetaires et locataires. L'aobat de grandes supeifioies de terrains et leur revente parpetites parodies aprZ lotisse- ment et amelioration donnera un profit trZ appreciable. Do plas la Society se obargera de oonstruire, pour oompte des aoquereurs et pour son propre oompte, des immeubles de rapport et des villas, d'oii nouvelle souroe de benefioes oertains, dtant donnd que la plupart des mem bres aotifs de la Sooiete ont fait leurs preuve^ dans oes diverses branobes. La Sooiete se obargera egalcment de tous travaux pour le oompte du Gouvernement ou pour les partiouliers. La Sooiete s'est, d'ores et ddjk, assure les conoours ndoessairoa pour traiter, en participation avec des groupes looaux et etrangers, les affaires dont Fimportanoe ddpasserait ses moyens immediate; elle aura, par oontre, l'option de partioiper aux affaires qa'entrepren- draient css groupes. En resume, la Society oompte bdndfioier, dans une trZ large proportion, du ddvelopp - ment doonomiqae da pays. Il est facile de so rendre compte que, mgme Bi son activity se limitait au Cairo et k sa banlieue, Fextension extraordinaire que prend la Capitale, la construction do quartiers nouveaux, les importantes transactions qui se font presqae joarnellemeut sur les terrains, l'avantage considerable qu'il y a a acheter en gros pour lotir, les bdadfioes important^ resultant des courtages provenant des achats et reveutes pour oompte des tiers, tout csla suffirait amplement a lui asiurer un vaste obamp de travail. La Society a ddjk a l'dtude plusieurs projets important# qui se presentent dans des conditions exoeptionellement rdmundratrioes et qui ont, en outre, Fa vantage d'dfcre rdalisables dans un trZ bref ddlai. Le Conseil d'Administration de la Societe d"Entreprises Immobiltiree et de Travaux est compose d'hommes oompetents et pratique-, qai, par leur connaissanoe approfondie da payp, par leurs relatious avec les administration?, oompagnies et entrepnses sont en mesure de pouvoir assurer les meiileures affaires k la So ciete. De plas, il y a lieu de oonsiderer qae, grAoe k la formation specials de ce Conseil, tout le travail, achat et revente de terrains, courtages, entrepnses, oonstruotion et administration, sera fait par la Society mdme sans l'aide d'interme diairej, de sorte qae la somme entiZe des be ndfic38 realises resteraacqaise aaxactionnaires.

div.head: Ciroulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Pour Finstant, l'attention se porte prinoipale ment sur Algesiras. On ne oroit gukre que la paix puisse 6tre compromise, quelle que soit Fissue de la Conference; mais la speculation semble toujouraapprdhender qnelquepeu l'ef- fet des noavelles tendanoieases qui pourraient fitre lanodes dans la vue de determiner un mouvement de reaction, mouvement qui ne saurait 6tre trZ sdrieux et serait, d'ailleurs, tout k fait traniitoire. Avant-hier, au Stook-Exobange, le Consolide anglais a baissd de 1/8 k 90 5/8 et l'Unifies de 1/4 k 104 7/8. La National Bank et la Daira sont restdes inobangdes k 27 7/8. L'Agrioole a fldohi de 1/8 k 10. A Paris, Faction Credit Foncier Egyptien a reagi de 5 franos k 805. La Banque d'Athknes est, par contre, remontee k 189. • Notre marohd des valours, a dtd, ce matin, assez ferme, quoique moins anime qae oes jours derniers, notamment dans le oompartiment des Banques. La National Bank a donne lieu k peu d'doarts pour oldturor plus ou moins k son oours d'avant-bier, soit 27 8/4. L'Agrioole, plus monvementde et en bonne tendanoe, a avauod k 10 3/16—1/4; la nouvelle emission k98/4— 18/16. Le Comptoir Financier a encore progresse k 5 7/16. Saivant des informations d'Alexandrie, il est qaestion d'ane nouvelle emission de oette Society dont le oapital de £ 200,000 serait, ditron, double. L'aotion Credit Foncier s'est maintenue entre 807-808. Les parts de jouissanoe Eiux du Caire sont revenues k 262. Les Agriooles du Nil ont monte k 255 et les Improvements Corporation k 5 1/16. L'aotion Enterprise and Development s'est insorite k 11 13/16; la partde fondateur k 10. Le Wardan Estate a ete cote k 7 5/8. Dsns le groupe des Hotels, les Baebler ont avanoe k 4 o/8 et les National k 4 1/4 avec de nombreuses transactions. Les Nungovioh res- tent ddlaissds k 18 11/16. Parmi les petites valours, le mouvement de hausse, quo nous avions fait pressentir, s'est encore aooentae sur les Delta Land ; la de* mande est grande et le oours a attaint 2 7/16— 1/2; des noavelles trZ favorables oirculent re* lativement k cette Sooidtd. Les Oasis et lee Hooker se tieoftent aux abords da pair. Les Cotton (Mills sont restZ k 7 sh., les Markets k 26 sh\et les Glymenopoulo k 1 5/16. La soasoription aux 10,000 actions, offertes au publio, de la Society d'Entroprisea Im- mobilidros et de Travaux, dont nous avons parie avant-hier, aura lieu aprZ-demain, mer- credi 14 fdvrier, et le jour saivant, auxguiohets de 1'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, au Cairo et k Alexandria de 9 heures k midi, et de 3 k 5 p.m. Les liatea de soasoription seront ouvertes oes deux jours seulement. Nous nous mettons k 1'entiZe disposition de ceux de nos olients qui voudraient sousoriro par notre entremise. D'aprZ des informations tdldgraphiqaes de Londres, on oonfirmait, samedi passe, an Stock- Exchange, la nouvelle—dejk mentiounde dans notro Ciroulaire do 17 janvier—que le dividen- de de la National Bank of Egypt pour Fexeroioe 1905 serait de 2 % supdrieur k oelui de l'annee prdoddente, soit 18 sh. par aotion, dquivabnt k 9 % sur le oapital nominal. * • * On ne tardera pas k dtre fixe sur le montant du dividende qui sera distribue le mois pro chain par l'Egyptian Estates Co. L'exeioioe financier de cette Society expire, comme on le sait, le 28 da oourant. * * * A a so jet de la Western Egypt Corporation, on annonoe que M. Beckett, rdcemment revenu au Cairo de son inspection dans les Oasis, est parti hier pour Londres afia de s'entendro avec le ooneeil d'administration sur les mesureB k prendre pour aotiver les operations de la Socie- ty. M. Beckett sera de reboar vers la fin du mois. * * Marche da cotou. — Ls Mars, qui avait fini samedi passe k 17 3/4, a ouvert, ce matin, k 18 pour oldtarer k 18 3/16. On noas ckble de Liverpool qae, malgre l'e- tat apathique des marches de oette place et de New-York, le oom mere 3 anglais et americain est trZ aotif. On a reja k Manchester des ordres important# provenant de la Chine Orientals. * * * MM. H. de Vries et Boutigny, age its de ohange, se ebargent de Fexecation de tons ordres de Bourse (valears et merchandises) ear lea marches de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, An- vers, Liverpool et New York.
